Anxiety.intro: Anxiety is a common emotional experience involving excessive fear or worry. While some anxiety is normal, persistent and overwhelming anxiety can interfere with school, relationships, and daily life.
symptoms: Physical symptoms like stomach aches or headaches
Anxiety.prevalence: Anxiety problems affect an estimated 7–10% of school-aged children worldwide, and rates have increased post-COVID.
prevention: Promote open communication at home and school
Encourage physical activity and healthy routines
Reduce exposure to stressful situations when possible
management: Practice mindfulness and stress-reduction exercises
Talk to a school counselor or mental health professional
Limit caffeine and screen time before bed
Keep a daily routine and sleep schedule
Join support groups or peer mentoring programs
Anxiety.notes: Anxiety can manifest in students as test anxiety, social anxiety, or general anxiety about the future. For example, a student may avoid presentations due to fear of being judged.
Anxiety.prevalence_literature: According to the National Institute of Mental Health, anxiety problems are the most common mental illness in the U.S., affecting 31.9% of adolescents aged 13–18.

Depression.intro: Depression is more than just feeling sad or moody. It's a serious mental health condition that affects how someone feels, thinks, and acts, leading to problems in daily functioning.
Depression.prevalence: Depression affects around 1 in 5 adolescents globally and is one of the leading causes of disability in young people.
prevention: Build strong social and emotional skills
Promote a culture of support and empathy
management: Seek professional counseling or therapy
Maintain regular sleep, meals, and exercise
Use journaling or art to express emotions
Stay connected with trusted friends or mentors
Medication may be prescribed in severe cases
Depression.notes: A depressed student may struggle to get out of bed, lose interest in friends or activities, and perform poorly in school. For instance, consistent low mood over weeks may indicate clinical depression.
Depression.prevalence_literature: The World Health Organization states that depression is the fourth leading cause of illness and disability among adolescents aged 15–19 years.

Stress.intro: Stress is the body's response to pressure or threat. School stress in students often comes from academic demands, social challenges, and extracurricular expectations.
Stress.prevalence: Up to 75% of students report feeling stressed about schoolwork or exams.
prevention: Teach time management and study skills
Foster a safe and open environment to discuss concerns
management: Use breathing and relaxation techniques
Talk to a teacher, parent, or counselor
Get regular physical activity and sleep
Practice mindfulness and self-care
Limit multitasking and overcommitment
Stress.notes: Stress in students often arises before major exams or when juggling academics with extracurriculars. Chronic stress can reduce academic performance and emotional resilience.
Stress.prevalence_literature: Surveys by the American Psychological Association report that 45% of teens say they are stressed by school pressures.

Childhood Trauma.intro: Childhood trauma involves exposure to events such as abuse, neglect, or family violence, which can severely impact emotional development and mental health.
Childhood Trauma.prevalence: Approximately 1 in 4 children experience a traumatic event by age 16.
prevention: Create safe, stable, and nurturing relationships
Raise awareness about child abuse and neglect
Support parents and caregivers through education
Establish clear safety protocols at schools
Encourage early intervention in high-risk families
management: Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT)
Build trust through consistent support
Safe space to talk about experiences
Teach emotional regulation skills
Involve caregivers in the healing process
Childhood Trauma.notes: Examples of trauma include witnessing domestic violence, losing a parent, or surviving an accident. Such experiences can disrupt emotional development and behavior in school.
Childhood Trauma.prevalence_literature: The CDC-Kaiser ACE study found that 61% of adults had at least one adverse childhood experience (ACE), which increases the risk of future mental health issues.

Low Self-Esteem.intro: Low self-esteem is a negative perception of oneself and often leads to feelings of inadequacy, shame, or lack of confidence.
Low Self-Esteem.prevalence: Many adolescents experience dips in self-esteem, especially during transitional periods such as puberty.
management: Use affirmations and gratitude journals
Set realistic goals and track progress
Encourage hobbies and passions
Counseling or mentorship programs
Teach assertiveness and communication skills
Low Self-Esteem.notes: A student may constantly criticize themselves or avoid leadership roles due to fear of failure. Affirmation exercises and supportive environments can improve self-worth.
Low Self-Esteem.prevalence_literature: Research shows that self-esteem typically drops during early adolescence due to puberty and social comparison but can recover with proper support.

Body Shaming & Dysmorphic Disorder.intro: Body shaming involves criticizing someone's physical appearance and can lead to Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD), where a person is obsessed with perceived flaws.
Body Shaming & Dysmorphic Disorder.prevalence: BDD affects about 2% of adolescents, often going undiagnosed due to stigma.
prevention: Limit social media that promotes unrealistic standards
management: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)
Media literacy education
Limit mirror-checking and avoidance behaviors
Involve family in treatment
Medication may be used for severe cases
Body Shaming & Dysmorphic Disorder.notes: A teenager who constantly compares themselves to influencers may feel ashamed of their appearance. This can escalate to body dysmorphia, affecting self-image and mental health.
Body Shaming & Dysmorphic Disorder.prevalence_literature: The International OCD Foundation notes that BDD affects about 1.7% to 2.9% of the general population, with onset usually in adolescence.

Substance Use.intro: Substance use  involves the harmful or hazardous use of drugs or alcohol. It can affect academic performance and increase the risk of mental health problems.
symptoms: Physical signs like red eyes or slurred speech
Substance Use.prevalence: Around 5% of adolescents globally report substance misuse, often starting in high school.
prevention: Educate early about risks of drug use
management: Seek professional help from counselors or rehab programs
Participate in group therapy or 12-step programs
Address underlying emotional or psychological issues
Avoid triggers and risky environments
Rebuild trust and family support
Substance Use.notes: Teen substance use often begins with experimentation at social events but may progress to regular use, especially when used to cope with emotional pain.
Substance Use.prevalence_literature: UNODC data shows that 5.6% of 15–16-year-olds reported using cannabis at least once in the past year.

Sleep problems.intro: Sleep problems in students can include insomnia, delayed sleep phase syndrome, and poor sleep hygiene. These conditions affect concentration, mood, and academic success.
Sleep problems.prevalence: Approximately 30–40% of adolescents suffer from sleep disturbances.
prevention: Stick to a consistent sleep schedule
Create a quiet and dark sleep environment
Educate about the importance of sleep hygiene
management: Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I)
Establish bedtime routines
Use relaxation exercises before bed
Reduce stress through daily planning
Consult a sleep specialist if persistent
Sleep problems.notes: Students may stay up late due to device use, affecting sleep quality. This leads to fatigue and concentration issues in class, commonly seen in teens with delayed sleep phase syndrome.
Sleep problems.prevalence_literature: The Sleep Foundation reports that 70% of high school students do not get enough sleep on school nights.

Eating problems.intro: Eating problems such as anorexia, bulimia, and binge-eating disorder involve unhealthy eating habits that negatively affect physical and mental health.
Eating problems.prevalence: Eating problems affect around 5% of adolescents, with many cases emerging during teenage years.
prevention: Promote healthy relationships with food and body
management: Seek treatment from specialists in eating problems
Nutritional counseling and meal planning
Psychotherapy such as CBT or family-based therapy
Medical monitoring for physical complications
Support from family and peer groups
Eating problems.notes: Teens might skip meals or over-exercise to meet body ideals portrayed in media. These behaviors often go unnoticed until severe health issues arise.
Eating problems.prevalence_literature: NIMH reports that eating problems have the highest mortality rate of any mental disorder, with peak onset during adolescence.

Suicidal behaviors.intro: Suicidal behaviors refer to thoughts, plans, or actions intended to cause one's own death. These behaviors are often linked to mental health conditions such as depression, anxiety, trauma, or substance use.
symptoms: Talking about wanting to die or feeling hopeless
Increased use of alcohol or drugs
Giving away prized possessions or saying goodbye
Suicidal behaviors.prevalence: Globally, suicide is the fourth leading cause of death among 15–29-year-olds. In many countries, adolescent suicide rates have been rising.
prevention: Early identification and treatment of mental health issues
Reducing access to means (e.g., firearms, medications)
Promoting open conversations about mental health
Training school staff to recognize warning signs
management: Immediate safety planning and risk assessment
Psychotherapy such as Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) or Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT)
Medication for underlying mental health conditions
Emergency intervention if the person is in immediate danger
Family and school-based support and follow-up
Suicidal behaviors.notes: Many suicidal individuals show warning signs. Early intervention and support can be life-saving. Encouraging young people to talk about their feelings without judgment is critical.
Suicidal behaviors.prevalence_literature: According to the World Health Organization, more than 700,000 people die by suicide every year. Adolescents and young adults are particularly vulnerable.
